Biomass-derived chemicals can be transformed into chemicals with higher commercial value [1,2]. In this respect, upgrading bio-based sugars into furans has gained significant momentum over the past few years [3]. Furfural is a colorless and transparent chemical produced by hydrolysis and dehydration of pentosan in plant fiber raw materials (such as corn cob, oat husk, cottonseed husk, bagasse, rice husk, etc.). It is an important raw material for synthetic resins, electrical insulating materials, nylon, coatings, etc., and raw materials and reagents for preparing drugs and various organic syntheses [4]. Furfural yield depends on the two reactions of furfural formation and furfural decomposition. In addition to the characteristics of raw materials, factors that affect the output of furfural include the type and concentration of catalyst, solid-liquid ratio, temperature, steam consumption, and the flow state of steam in the material layer [5]. It has been reported that xylose and arabinose can be obtained by acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of agricultural and forestry raw materials with high pentosan content, which are the primary 5-C sugar raw materials for the synthesis of furfural. Xylose is then catalytically dehydrated to furfural. Therefore, developing high-efficiency and highly-stable catalysts has become urgent to improve production efficiency [6]. This paper will focus on the design, preparation, and evaluation of catalysts for the dehydration of xylose to obtain furfural. The catalysts currently used to catalyze furfural production from xylose mainly include homogeneous and heterogeneous Catalysts. Among homogeneous catalysts, sulfuric acid and hydrochloric acid are the most widely used in the industrial production of furfural [7]. However, the organic acid-catalyzed polymerization of xylose or xylan-producing furfural-prone products to form solid humus results in furfural yields of up to 65% [8]. AlCl3 is reportedly an excellent catalyst for the dehydration of xylose to furfural. An 84.8% furfural yield was obtained from xylan at 443 K and a reaction time of 10 s [9]. However, inorganic acids are highly corrosive to equipment, and it is challenging to recover the catalyst from the reaction mixture, suggesting they cannot be reused [10]. Solid catalysts are ideal substitutes for homogeneous catalysts due to their recyclability and good stability. Hydrogen molecular sieve [11–13], ion exchange resin [14–17], metal oxide [18–20], carbon-based catalyst [19–24], and metal-organic framework (MOF) materials [25,26] are capable of providing B- or l- acid catalytic active sites and can catalyze the conversion of xylose to furfural. Hydrotalcite is a new class of anionic layered compounds [27] that has become a promising tool based on its unique characteristics. Changes can be made to the chemical composition of the host laminate, the type and quantity of interlayer guest anions, and the particle size and distribution of the intercalation assembly. Hydrotalcite materials have been extensively used as potential new inorganic functional materials for catalyzing various reactions [28–30]. An increasing body of evidence suggests that hydrotalcite materials can catalyze the conversion of xylose to furfural [31–33]. The above findings suggest that the hydrotalcite material can act as a catalyst for the synthesis of furfural by degradation of xylose. It has been established that converting xylose to furfural reaction includes isomerization of xylose to xylulose and dehydration and cyclization of xylulose to synthesize furfural. Isomerization is catalyzed by Brønsted base or Lewis acid, while Lewis or Brønsted acids catalyze dehydration [34,35]. Only the bifunctional catalysts Lewis acid and Brønsted acid have been reported to synergize the isomerization and dehydration cyclization of xylose to produce furfural. To our knowledge, no study has hitherto successfully used Brønsted base plus Lewis acid bifunctional catalyst to catalyze the conversion of xylose to furfural [36,37]. The present study sought to use hydrotalcite to prepare an LDH-derived catalyst with Lewis acid and Brønsted base catalytic sites. With this bifunctional catalyst, isomerization and dehydration could be simultaneously completed on the integrated catalyst. 2 Experiments and methods 2.1 Materials Xylose and furfural were purchased from Energy Chemical Co., Ltd., PR China. Al(NO3)3·9H2O, CrCl3·6H2O, MgCl2·6H2O, and Methyl sulfoxide (DMSO) were purchased from Macklin Chemical Co., Ltd., PR China. All reagents used in this research were analytically pure and used as received without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of Al-Mg-LDH and Cr-Mg-LDH Al-Mg-LDH and Cr-Mg-LDH were prepared by the coprecipitation method. Briefly, a solution containing Mg2+ (MgCl2·6H2O) (13 g in 200 mL deionized water) and Al3+ (Al(NO3)3·9H2O) or Cr3+ (CrCl3·6H2O) was coprecipitated at pH 9 adjusted by using 2 M NaOH. After coprecipitation, the solution was vigorously stirred for 1 h and maintained at 343 K for 24 h. After aging, the precipitate was filtered and dried at 353 K for 24 h in a vacuum drying oven. During Lewis acid screening, the mass ratio of Al3+ (Al(NO3)3·9H2O) to Mg2+ (MgCl2·6H2O) was 4:15, and the mass ratio of Cr3+ (CrCl3·6H2O) to Mg2+ (MgCl2·6H2O) was 13:30. The samples were denoted as Cr-Mg-LDH or Al-Mg-LDH. 2.3 Synthesis of Cr-Mg-LDO Cr-Mg-LDHs samples were calcined at 673 K for 4 h under N2 to obtain Cr-Mg-LDO (where LDO means calcined hydrotalcite). The solids were named x-LDO where x (x = 13:30, 13:20, 13:15 or 13:10) corresponds to the M3+/M2+ mass ratio value. 2.4 Characterization Conventional instrument characterization: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were recorded on a desktop scanning electron microscope (Phenom Pro-X, CN). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Nexus 670 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. X-ray diffraction was analyzed on a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer system (XRD; Rint 2000, Rigaku). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms between RT to 1173 K were tested by a volumetric adsorption apparatus (ASAP 2460, USA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) with EscaLab 250Xi (Thermo, Waltham, USA) apparatus was analyzed using an Al Kα excitation source (hv = 1486.6 eV). Before analysis, the sample was pretreated at 353 K under a vacuum for at least 2 h to remove adsorbed moisture. XPS data were analyzed by XPSPEAK software to visualize the results. A thermogravimetric analyzer was used to measure the thermal stability of the various groups carried with Mettler TGA(Mettler Toledo, Switzerland) under a nitrogen atmosphere (50 mL/min) with a warming rate of 10 K/min. The acidity and basicity of the prepared catalyst were analyzed using NH3-TPD with the TP-5080 Chemical Adsorption Apparatus (Tianjin Xianquan Industry and Trade Development Co., Ltd., China). Semi-quantitative analysis of metal elements was determined using Benchtop Energy Dispersive X-ray Fluorescence (XRF) Spectrometer. (Epsilon 3XLE, Malvern Panalytical Ltd., Netherlands). The particle size distribution analysis of the prepared catalytic materials was carried out using a laser particle size analyzer Mastersize 2000. 2.5 Catalytic experiment 2.5.1 Transformation reaction of xylose Catalytic performance was evaluated based on xylose conversion efficiency and furfural yield. First, the catalyst, water/DMSO, and xylose were mixed in a pressure-resistant thick-walled glass bottle. Next, the oil bath was heated to 373 K or 393 K under magnetic stirring for 0–20 h. The reaction contents were stopped by ice water. Xylose in the mixture was measured by High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with a Bio-red chromatography column. An Agilent liquid phase fitted with an ultraviolet sensor and C18 chromatography column was adopted to detect and analyze furfural. All reactions were performed in duplicates. 2.5.2 Recyclability of the Cr-Mg-LDO catalysts The catalyst was used at least five times during the transformation of xylose at 393 K for 6 h to determine the efficiency of the recycled catalyst. The insoluble catalysts were easily separated using simple filtration and washed with hot ethanol and distilled water to remove the adsorbed reactants and products. The recovered catalyst was activated each time by heating at 333 K for 12 h in a vacuum-drying oven. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Comparison of aluminum and chromium as trivalent metals sources There is an increasing consensus that metal chloride salts, including Lewis acids, can efficiently catalyze the production of furan compounds from monosaccharides [38–40]. In recent years, the preparation of metal salts as catalytic sites in solid catalysts to produce furfural has been extensively documented [41–43]. Inspired by these findings, we selected two trivalent metal chloride salts reported in the literature for preparing hydrotalcite for catalyst screening. We successfully prepared two hydrotalcite through the coprecipitation method. Al3+ and Cr3+ were used as trivalent metal ion sources to form the corresponding Al-Mg-LDH and Cr-Mg-LDH hydrotalcite. Al3+ and Cr3+ and their chlorine salts are commonly used homogeneous catalysts in transforming monose to furan. Fig. 1 a shows the infrared spectra of Al-Mg-LDH and Cr-Mg-LDH. The broad spectra peak at about 3400 cm−1 was due to the stretching vibration of the OH bond, and the corresponding OH bond bending vibration at 1620 cm−1 was due to the water, indicating the presence of water or hydroxyl on the surface of LDHs, which conforms to the Laminar structure in LDH(Layer Double Hydroxides) [44]. In the FTIR spectra of Al-Mg-LDH, the 750–1320 cm−1 peak corresponded to the interlayer N=O and NO [45], while the interlayer of Cr-Mg-LDH was Cl-intercalated [46], accounting for only a weak response in the 750–1320 cm−1 band in the FTIR spectra. In addition, peaks below 600 cm−1 were attributed to metal-oxygen-metal vibration [47]. Fig. 1b shows the results of the X-ray diffractometer spectral analysis; the sharp and symmetrical peaks indicate that the materials were successfully synthesized and these LDHs exhibited good crystallinity and purity. The XRD spectra of Al-Mg-LDH exhibited six peaks and crystalline planes at 2θ of 24°(006), 35°(015), 39°(012), 46°(200), 62°(220), and 66°(303), which belonged to the Al/Mg hydrotalcite structure [48]. The characteristic peaks of Cr-Mg-LDH were observed at 46°(200), 60°(220), and 76° (311), which can be attributed to the porous MgO nanosheet(JCPDS card no. 45–0946). Since the peaks of Cr-containing oxides were not apparent in the XRD pattern, we conducted XPS and XRF to analyze the oxidation valence state of the Cr atoms in the prepared materials in the following research. The FTIR and XRD results substantiated that we successfully constructed layered hydrotalcite materials. Besides, the morphology of LDHs was observed by SEM (supporting information). The morphologies of Al-Mg-LDH and Cr-Mg-LDH can be observed in Figures S1 and S2, respectively. SEM observation showed that the prepared materials exhibited a lamellar structure, and the lamellar structure of Al-Mg-LDH was thinner than Cr-Mg-LDH. However, the transverse dimensions of Al-Mg-LDH lamellae were significantly greater than Cr-Mg-LDH lamellae. The performance of the prepared LDH catalysts was evaluated. As shown in Table 1 , Cr-Mg-LDH exhibited better catalytic activity than Al-Mg-LDH. The catalyst containing Cr yielded better activity than Al, which may be attributed to the higher activity of Al salt in catalyzing the degradation of furfural [49]. According to the above experimental results, we used CrCl3 as the trivalent metal source to prepare LDH materials in the subsequent experiments. During the follow-up study, we obtained the optimal catalysts by synthesizing LDH materials composed of Cr and Mg hydroxides with different metal ratios, comparing their catalytic properties and structural differences, and elucidating the structure-function relationship. 3.2 Effect of the metal ratio on catalytic active of Cr-Mg-LDHs As shown in Fig. 2 a and b, xylose conversion gradually slowed when treated with Cr-Mg-LDH catalysts. Higher divalent metal concentration in the hydrotalcite catalyst was associated with higher xylose conversion at the same reaction time. In this regard, peak xylose conversion was observed when the M2+/M3+ ratio reached 13:30. On the other hand, furfural formation decreased from 50.3% to 41.29% when the mass ratio of M3+ decreased. These findings suggest that xylose conversion positively correlated with the mass ratio of M3+ vs. M2+. In addition, xylose and furfural conversion without catalyst (not displayed in the figures) were low, especially xylose conversion, which reached 5% in 20 h. Due to the intense UV detection limit, although the furfural yield can be detected, it is calculated within the error limit (2%). So we could regard the production as none. Next, we characterized the prepared Cr-Mg-LDH catalysts with different metal ratios. From the FTIR spectra (Fig. 3 a), the peaks at 3400 cm−1, 1640 cm-1 and 400–700 cm−1 were attributed to the stretching vibration of HO in the water molecules between the layers of hydrotalcite, the bending vibration of HO-H, and the vibration of M-O-H. The XRD patterns (Fig. 3b) demonstrated that the crystalline phase of the Cr-Mg-LDH was successfully formed; the sharper the peak, the better the crystal structure. Furthermore, the lamellar structure of the obtained hydrotalcite was more hierarchical. The particle size of the catalyst can affect mass transfer and separation and is an essential parameter for the quality of the catalyst. Besides, the particle size of the hydrotalcite material can also be used as an evaluation index for successful material preparation. As shown in Fig. 4 , different particle size curves of LDH materials prepared with different M3+/M2+ ratios were observed, implying that the mass ratio of M3+/M2+ would affect the size of the obtained hydrotalcite. When the mass ratio of M3+/M2+ was 13:20, the average particle size of the prepared catalyst was 250 µm, and particles with sizes ranging from 100 to 400 µm accounted for 90%. When the mass ratio of M3+/M2+ was 13:30, 90% of the prepared hydrotalcite was nanometer. 3.3 Effect of calcination on catalyst activity It has been reported that catalytic activity at the active site (Brønsted basic sites) of LDH materials could be improved by calcination [50]. Although the alkalinity of LDH is the same as its divalent metal hydroxide, LDH always has a small specific surface area (about 5–20 m2/g), leading to low apparent alkalinity. LDO generally has a higher specific surface area (about 200–300 m2/g), and alkali centers are fully exposed, making it more alkaline than LDH. Accordingly, the strong basicity of LDH often manifests in its calcined LDO product. Generally speaking, the recovery of the structure is possible when the calcination temperature is within 773 K. Taking Al-Mg-LDHs as an example, the structure of the calcined product at a temperature of 773 K could be partially restored to the ordered layered structure after exposure to water. At calcination temperatures above 873 K, a calcined product with a spinel structure was formed, leading to the failure of the structure to recover [51]. To further improve the catalytic performance of the prepared catalyst, we adopted high-temperature calcination to produce more active sites. When the M3+/M2+ ratio was changed, the Cr-Mg-LDO catalyst prepared with calcination showed significant differences from non-calcined Cr-Mg-LDHs. As shown in Fig. 5 a and b, when the ratio of M3+/M2+ was 13:20, the prepared Cr-Mg-LDO exhibited optimal catalytic activity for xylose transformation, with an optimal Furfural yield of 50.3%. In contrast, when the ratio of M3+/M2+ was 13:30, the catalyst obtained yielded peak catalytic activity for xylose degradation. By comparing Figs. 2 and 5, the LDO catalyst significantly improved catalytic efficiency (xylose conversion rate and furfural yield) compared with the LDH catalyst, independent of the metal ratio. As shown in Fig. 5b, the color curves exhibited the accumulation of xylulose. Xylulose formation occurred during the early stage of the reaction, and the optimal yield was reached within 6 h, then dropped to almost zero at 12 h (Fig. 5b). This finding suggested that xylulose is an intermediate product. At the end of the reaction, xylulose was depleted. For hydrotalcite catalysts with different L/B ratios, when the ratio of M3+/M2+ was 13:20, the peak accumulation of xylose in the reaction process was 13.97%, which was significantly higher than catalysts with other metal ratios, and the trend was the same as the optimal yield of furfural. This finding also indicated that the isomerization of xylose to xylose promoted the formation of furfural, consistent with the literature [52,53]. Next, we explored the mechanism underlying the ability of the calcination process to enhance catalytic performance through structural characterization analysis. Compared with the corresponding LDH catalysts, the peaks at 3400 cm−1 and 1640 cm−1 of those catalysts prepared by calcination became smaller due to the loss of water molecules between layers [54]. The functional groups of hydrotalcite material displayed in the FTIR spectra were not altered (Fig. 6 a vs. Fig. 3a). Besides, the position of the characteristic peaks of metal oxides was not changed (Fig. 3b vs. Fig. 6b). The FTIR and XRD spectra indicated that the initial crystalline structure was retained after calcination. However, the oxidation state of Cr peaks in LDO material was not as evident in the XRD pattern as in LDH. Therefore, we used XRF characterization methods to substantiate the presence of Cr in the synthesized material. Table 2 presents the XRF and XPS data of the prepared LDO catalytic materials. As shown in Table 2, the main oxide form of Cr in the ready hydrotalcite-like catalyst material was Cr2O3. When the mass ratio of the trivalent metal source to the divalent metal source was 13:20 and 13:15, the prepared chromium's mass ratio of Cr2O3 in the magnesium hydrotalcite catalyst was about 50%. When the proportion of trivalent metals in the raw material continues to increase or decrease, the mass ratio of Cr oxide in the prepared chromium-magnesium hydrotalcite binary compound system was consistently above 60%. It is worth noting that the catalyst which yielded the best performance had the lowest L/B value (1.08) of 13:20-LDO, suggesting that the high proportion of active centers of Bronster base can cause a high xylose isomerization reaction, thus promoting the final Lewis acid-catalyzed dehydration of xylose to furfural. It can be seen from the table that there are significant differences in element proportion results obtained by XRF and XPS caused by different test principles. For example, XRF can not detect carbon, whereas XPS inevitably has carbon peaks. However, we can still see from the data that the L/B molar ratio of 13:20-LDO was significantly lower than that of 13:30-LDO and 13:15-LDO. In other words, it has a higher molar ratio of Brønsted base sites. For catalyst 13:10-LDO, the considerable difference in L/B between XRF and XPS may be due to the different test depths of the two test methods. We also compared the relevant L/B values of Al-Mg-LDH and Cr-Mg-LDH with LDO catalytic materials (table 2, entries 1 and 2). The L/B value of the hydrotalcite materials prepared with Al as a trivalent metal source is significantly higher than the hydrotalcite catalytic materials prepared with Cr as a trivalent metal source. Based on the results of the above experiments, we conclude that the optimal ratio of M3+/M2+ for preparing LDO was 13:20 with a peak furfural yield of 50.3%. The percentage of bare metal ions could affect the Cr content of the synthesized catalytic materials (Table 2), the crystallinity integrity (Fig. 6b), and thus the catalytic activity changes (Fig. 5). After obtaining the optimal catalyst, we conducted XPS, NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD, TG, and BET characterization to understand the catalytic mechanism of calcined chromium-magnesium hydrotalcite. From the XPS spectra (Fig. 7 a), both Mg-Cr-LDH and Mg-Cr-LDO revealed Cr 2p2/3 peaks at 576.5 eV and 577.0 eV, corresponding to Cr3+ oxide and hydroxide, respectively [42]. A double peak was observed for O 1 s instead of a single peak (Fig. 7c), indicating that calcination produced oxygen vacancies in the material [48]. NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD were used to analyze the acidity and basicity of the catalyst surface (Fig. 8 a and b). The results showed that the characteristics of the prepared LDH and LDO materials are both acidic and basic. A comparison of LDH and LDO (Fig. 8a and b) showed that the characteristic peak near 700 K decreased after calcination. In contrast, a new distinct peak was observed near 880 K, indicating that the hydrotalcite surface's acid strength and alkalinity were improved after calcination. Fig. 9 a shows the thermogravimetric analysis results of the prepared LDH and LDO materials. It was found that weight loss of the LDH material before calcination was mainly concentrated in the two temperature ranges of 300–500 K and 700–1000 K. Weight loss of TGA at 300–500 K and 700–1000 K may be attributed to dehydroxylation and decarbonization, respectively [55–57]. Moreover, total weight loss from room temperature to 1200 K is about 25%. Compared with LDH, the thermal stability of LDO material obtained after calcination was significantly improved. As shown in Fig. 9b, BET surface area analysis results demonstrated that the specific surface area of the calcined catalyst increased from 15.58 m2·g−1(LDH) to 39.22 m2·g−1 (LDO), and the pore size decreased from 16.92 nm to 13.74 nm. Taken together, we infer that the catalytic enhancement of LDO may be associated with both base and acid enhancement and increased specific surface area. As shown in Fig. 10 a and d, Cr-Mg-LDH and Cr-Mg-LDO were hexagonal grains with few hydroxide agglomerations. The hexagonal grains had few hydroxide agglomerations. Cr-Mg-LDO showed a disk-shaped nanosheet structure with a transverse dimension of about 1–2 µm and a thickness of about 30 nanometers. Most Cr-Mg-LDH particles exhibited an irregular morphology, and only a few had hexagonal morphology. The lamellar sizes of Cr-Mg-LDH and Cr-Mg-LDO were significantly larger than MgO and CrO nanosheets [58,59], indicating the formation of a new lamellar structure through nucleation crystallization. EDS mapping of Cr-Mg-LDH (Fig. 10c) showed that Cr and Mg elements are evenly distributed throughout the material. As shown in the STEM micrograph of Cr-Mg-LDO (Fig. 10 ), the lamellar spacing of Cr-Mg-LDO was less than 1 nm. 3.4 Stability evaluation Analysis of the recyclability of solid catalysts revealed that the catalysts could reduce production costs. As shown in Fig. 10, Cr-Mg-LDO maintained good catalytic activity. After four cycles, the furfural yield was 24.4%, suggesting that the catalyst is relatively stable and potentially valuable in practical applications. The TG curve revealed that the Cr-Mg-LDO was relatively stable below 573 K (Fig. 9b). After the LDO catalyst was used for five cycles, the furfural yield slightly decreased. Therefore, we conclude that unreacted reagents did not affect the catalyst sites. 3.5 Comparison with catalysts reported in the literature Table 3 presents a comparison of the performance of the catalyst prepared in this paper with other catalysts that have been reported in the literature. As shown in Table 3, our catalyst offered a competitive furfural yield through catalytic conversion in a mixed solvent system under mild reaction conditions. When only metal oxides with Lewis acidity were used as catalysts (Table 3, entry 10) [60], the increase in activity required a combination with Bronster base catalyst to obtain satisfactory furfural yield (Table 3, entry 11) [60]. Although the final yield was not as good as the liquid-phase catalyst [61] and other heterogeneous catalysts, it was associated with a relatively low reaction temperature. 4 Conclusion The degradation of xylose by Mg-Cr-LDH with or without calcination has been investigated. The catalyst derived from hydrotalcite by calcination exhibited high catalytic activity for the benzylation of xylose. The synthesized Cr-Mg-LDO catalyst material exhibited a mesoporous structure with an average pore diameter of 13.73628 nm, a specific surface area of 39.2168 m2·g−1, and both acidic and basic bifunctional surface groups. When it was used to catalyze the conversion of xylose to furfural, a yield of 50.3% was obtained, along with good stability. This study substantiated that the as-prepared Cr-Mg-LDO catalyst material has huge prospects for application. coredata.dc:description: In this study, the coprecipitation method was used to synthesize a series of chromium-magnesium hydrotalcite materials. The trivalent and alkali metals in the materials acted as Lewis acid and Bronsted base catalysts, respectively. Its specific surface area was increased by calcining the chromium-magnesium hydrotalcite catalyst material. When dehydration of xylose to synthesize furfural was conducted at a temperature of 393 K for 16 h using a catalyst load of 100 mg and xylose substrate of 30 mg, a 50.3% yield was obtained at an optimal M3+/M2+ ratio of 13:20. The catalyst exhibited good stability, with 85.3% activity retained after being used for five cycles.
